content:
Yes, there have been instances where territorial transfers have led to positive outcomes and long-lasting peace. Sometimes, territorial transfers can be successful in resolving longstanding disputes and improving relations between countries. Here are some examples:

1. Alsace-Lorraine - The transfer of Alsace-Lorraine from Germany to France after World War I, as part of the Treaty of Versailles, has been credited with helping to improve relations between the two countries and contributing to the peace in Western Europe that lasted until the outbreak of World War II.

2. Hong Kong - The transfer of sovereignty over Hong Kong from the United Kingdom to China in 1997 was a peaceful transfer that has led to long-lasting peace and prosperity in the region.

3. South Tyrol - The transfer of South Tyrol from Austria to Italy in 1919 led to a period of conflict and tension, but over time, the region has become a model of peaceful coexistence between the German-speaking minority and the Italian-speaking majority.

4. Alaska - The transfer of Alaska from Russia to the United States in 1867 was a peaceful transfer that has led to long-lasting peace between the two countries.

Overall, while the transfer of territory can be a contentious issue, and can sometimes lead to further conflict, there have been instances where it has been successful in resolving disputes and improving relations between countries.
